Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..raw_text: Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N.Y. 339 (1928)
Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..proposition: - Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N.Y. 339 (1928) (proximate cause and foreseeability principles) (widely cited for proximate cause analysis).
Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..case_name: Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co.
Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..support_reasoning: The opinion is a canonical source for using foreseeability to define the scope of duty and thus limit proximate cause in negligence. Cardozo’s majority expressly frames liability in terms of whether the defendant’s conduct created a reasonably foreseeable risk to the particular plaintiff, and distinguishes issues of proximate cause and remoteness of damages from the antecedent question of duty. The cited proposition—that Palsgraf is widely cited for proximate cause and foreseeability analysis—is accurate and well supported by this text.
Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..relevant_excerpt: “The risk reasonably to be perceived defines the duty to be obeyed, and risk imports relation; it is risk to another or to others within the range of apprehension… These cases aside, wrong is defined in terms of the natural or probable, at least when unintentional… The law of causation, remote or proximate, is thus foreign to the case before us. The question of liability is always anterior to the question of the measure of the consequences that go with liability.”
